info.title: DivvyCloud v2 API
info.description:
DivvyCloud version 2 API documentation. This document is actively being updated. If you are looking for an action not documented here, please send us an email at support@divvycloud.com

Definitions:
- Public/Prototype: When the v2 api was started there was a desire to seperate UI specific or internally used endpoints into their own namespaces. All endpoints can be used but we caution use of prototype namespaced api endpoints as documentation and support may vary. Please contact us if you have any questions.
- X-Auth-Token: Endpoints are authenticated via session token explicitly passed in the header of a request. Sessions can be obtained using the login endpoint. When using the postman runner, logging in will set a session token for the postman environment. User credentials should be set as global postman variables.

post.description: Adding an AWS cloud account to DivvyCloud using AWS access key and AWS secret key.

Creates new insight.

get.description: Available Auto scaling Group actions.

cache-control.default: private, no-cache, no-store, no-transform, must-revalidate, max-age=0

post.description: Updating bagdes will only add the k:v pairs that are sent. i.g. if you currently have the following badge `badges: [{'cloud': 'aws'}]`, but in the update request you only send `badges:[{'cloud': 'gcp'}, {'cloud': 'azure'}]`,  `'cloud': 'aws'` will be removed and the other two badges will be persisted.
Returns a list of badges for a particular resource
Returns a list of badge counts for all resources.
Return a list of cloud accounts that are badged.

Create one or more badges for cloud account(s). If you are adding badges to multiple cloud accounts, the badges will all be the same for the multiple accounts chosen. Note this is an 18.1 feature. Previous versions are not supported.
Delete one or more badges from one or more cloud accounts. Note this is an 18.1 feature. Previous versions are not supported.

List all bots which are not archived.

Request supports `result list options` for pagination and filtering. Below is the minimum required options for the request.

```
{
	"filters": [],
	"limit": 25,
	"offset": 0
}
```
fetch bot by id.

Bots can be run ondemand which will apply the filters and actions to all resources within the scope of the bot.

If bot is configured to allow ondemand, this request will return `200` if the action succeeds.

Archiving bot will remove scheduled events, compliance data and hide the bot from listing calls as well as the botfactory page in the UI.

There is currently no way to un-archive a bot and this action should be seen as a delete.
Pausing bot will remove any pending scheduled events that the bot initiated. Once paused the bot will not run when hookpoint events happen nor will any user be able to run the bot ondemand.

Pausing bot will remove any pending scheduled events that the bot initiated. Resuming will start reacting to hookpoint events but to rescan all resources requires running the bot ondemand after resuming.

The edit endpoint takes an existing bot JSON config and applies any changes to the following keys with all other keys ignored:

* name
* description
* severity
* category
* instructions
* hookpoints
* ondemand_enabled
* state
* schedule

get.description: Returns a list of insights in packs

Provide the integer insight_id and the string source (backoffice or custom) to identify the insight. Returns a list of history records showing the counts and totals of resources matching the insight.

Both `insight_id` and `source` keys are present in each insight payload in list and get calls for insights.
Gets insight and information relating to it.

application/json.description: Identify database instances with a retention policy that is too low
application/json.notes:
## Overview

Retention periods for databases should typically include a minimum of seven daily backups. This allows administrators to go back in time for data analysis/retrieval purposes if/when an issue arrises. This insight is provided to surface databases with a retention policy of less than seven. Users can copy this insight to make a custom insight that more appropriately reflects their specific thresholds. Note that databases with automated backups disabled will also be included in the results.

### Remediation

- Increase the database retention period. Note that doing this can result in downtime if done outside of the normal maintenance window. The retention can be set in a manual fashion or automated using the `Set Backup Retention` action.


### Compliance Information
  - NIST Cyber Security Framework (CSF): PR.IP-4
  - GDPR: Article 30: Maintain Records of Processing Activities
  - SOC 2: A1.2
  - NIST 800-53: CP-9
application/json.name: Database Instance Retention Policy Too Low

post.description: Creates a new isolated environment. After creating organizations a domain admin user must switch contexts into the organization using the `Switch organization` endpoint.

After this request all future API requests made will be in the context of this organization. On the next login, the user will remain in the context of the last organization they were in.

Switching organizations is restricted to Domain Admins.
Changes name of organization. Organization names are globally unique for installations. Conflicting names will raise an error.

post.description: Create a named permission definition.

Update Role definition.

It's important to note that `All` permission, the api endpoint does not automatically set `view`, `provision`, `manage`, or `delete` to false. This means in the UI you will see all values selected. It has no negative effect but does make the presentation of the data less clear to end users.

Consider this and the create endpoints to be explicit APIs that require the exact permission rules you desire.

List all roles user has accesss to view

Requires Organization Admin

Params: Body

`resource_ids`: Resource IDs to add to the role scope.

`deprecated_resource_ids`: Resource IDs to remove from the role scope.

Requires Organization Admin

post.description:
Associate and Disassociate User groups from a role.

Params: Body

`group_resource_ids`: Resource IDs to add to the role's UserGroups. Compared with current User Groups set; additional ids are added, missing ids removed.

Requires Organization Admin

example.description: Identify database instances with a retention policy that is too low
example.notes:
## Overview

Retention periods for databases should typically include a minimum of seven daily backups. This allows administrators to go back in time for data analysis/retrieval purposes if/when an issue arrises. This insight is provided to surface databases with a retention policy of less than seven. Users can copy this insight to make a custom insight that more appropriately reflects their specific thresholds. Note that databases with automated backups disabled will also be included in the results.

### Remediation

- Increase the database retention period. Note that doing this can result in downtime if done outside of the normal maintenance window. The retention can be set in a manual fashion or automated using the `Set Backup Retention` action.


### Compliance Information
  - NIST Cyber Security Framework (CSF): PR.IP-4
  - GDPR: Article 30: Maintain Records of Processing Activities
  - SOC 2: A1.2
  - NIST 800-53: CP-9

tags.name: AutoScaling Groups
tags.description: Automatically scale up or down instances with user defined policies.

tags.name: Badges
tags.description: Badges provide a way to assign additional metadata about resources within the DivvyCloud platform. They are key/value pairs which can be used for filtering and identifying resources from parent cloud account.

tags.name: Botfactory
tags.description:
BotFactory is DivvyClouds answer to easy policy automation. The user is able to select from a list of predefined filters, which match resources, and actions, which act upon those resources. If the predefined filters and actions arent sufficient for a users needs, its possible to create new filters and actions that provide the needed functionality.

Components: scope, filters, and actions

BotFactory contains several components which comprise the system. They are scope, filters, actions, and when the bot should run.

Scope

Scope selects which cloud accounts bots should operate on. For managing multiple cloud accounts or if your list of accounts may change regularly, bots can be created to apply to all accounts with a Badge.

Filters

Filters specify what a bot should act upon. For example, a filter may match each resource based on tags that it does or does not have or it may match based on ports that are or are not open. There are numerous filters included with BotFactory and it is possible for a programmer to define her own.

Actions

Actions specify what a bot does. For example, an action may delete a resource, it may start or stop an instance, or it may send an email containing information about the evaluated resource. Actions are executed for a single resource at a time. When a bot possesses multiple actions, the actions are executed in order. There are numerous actions included with BotFactory. As with filters, it is possible for a programmer to define her own actions.

tags.name: Cache Instances
tags.description: Cache instances are managed systems with one or more caching technologies installed (eg: Redis).

tags.name: DNS Zones
tags.description: DNS Zones are portions within the global Domain Name Sysem.

tags.name: Identity Management
tags.description:
Identity Management provides an interface for managing admins, users and permissions.

The hierarchy of management can be understood as: Installation > Domains > Organizations > Groups/Roles/Users.

tags.name: Instances
tags.description: Compute Instances are virtual private servers. Examples of this would be AWS EC2 and Azure Virtual Machines.

tags.name: Organizations
tags.description: Organizations are isolated environments that contain cloud accounts, users and bots.

tags.name: Resource Access Lists
tags.description: Resource Access Lists are used to protect and ingress/egress traffic to cloud resources. Examples include Security Groups, Network Access Lists and Firewalls. This class inherits from TopLevelResource and has direct access to the resources database object.

tags.name: Roles
tags.description: Roles associate permissions with scope. Scopes are domains around resources in the system such as Clouds accounts, Resource Groups, and key, value attributes called Badges.

tags.name: User Groups - Role Based Access
tags.description: Collection of Users that can be associated with Roles for the purposes of Role Based Access

tags.name: Volumes
tags.description: A volume is a storage device that you can attach to an instance.
